trans-unit.source: Get started with SQL database auditing | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with SQL database auditing | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Get started with SQL database auditing
trans-unit.target: Get started with SQL database auditing

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database Auditing tracks database events and writes audited events to an audit log in your Azure Storage account. Auditing is generally available for Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database Auditing tracks database events and writes audited events to an audit log in your Azure Storage account. Auditing is generally available for Basic, Standard, and Premium service tiers.

trans-unit.source: Auditing can help you maintain regulatory compliance, understand database activity, and gain insight into discrepancies and anomalies that could indicate business concerns or suspected security violations.
trans-unit.target: Auditing can help you maintain regulatory compliance, understand database activity, and gain insight into discrepancies and anomalies that could indicate business concerns or suspected security violations.

trans-unit.source: Auditing tools enable and facilitate adherence to compliance standards but don't guarantee compliance.
trans-unit.target: Auditing tools enable and facilitate adherence to compliance standards but don't guarantee compliance.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure programs that support standards compliance, see the Azure Trust Center.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure programs that support standards compliance, see the Azure Trust Center.

trans-unit.source: [Azure SQL Database Auditing basics]
trans-unit.target: [Azure SQL Database Auditing basics]

trans-unit.source: [Set up auditing for your database]
trans-unit.target: [Set up auditing for your database]

trans-unit.source: [Analyze audit logs and reports]
trans-unit.target: [Analyze audit logs and reports]

trans-unit.source: The following sections describe the configuration of Auditing using the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: The following sections describe the configuration of Auditing using the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: You may also [Set up auditing for your database using the Classic Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: You may also [Set up auditing for your database using the Classic Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: SQL Database auditing allows you to:
trans-unit.target: SQL Database auditing allows you to:

trans-unit.source: Retain an audit trail of selected events.
trans-unit.target: Retain an audit trail of selected events.

trans-unit.source: You can define categories of database actions to be audited.
trans-unit.target: You can define categories of database actions to be audited.

trans-unit.source: Report on database activity.
trans-unit.target: Report on database activity.

trans-unit.source: You can use preconfigured reports and a dashboard to get started quickly with activity and event reporting.
trans-unit.target: You can use preconfigured reports and a dashboard to get started quickly with activity and event reporting.

trans-unit.source: Analyze reports.
trans-unit.target: Analyze reports.

trans-unit.source: You can find suspicious events, unusual activity, and trends.
trans-unit.target: You can find suspicious events, unusual activity, and trends.

trans-unit.source: You can configure auditing for the following event categories:
trans-unit.target: You can configure auditing for the following event categories:

trans-unit.source: Plain SQL and Parameterized SQL for which the collected audit logs are classified as
trans-unit.target: Plain SQL and Parameterized SQL for which the collected audit logs are classified as

trans-unit.source: Access to data
trans-unit.target: Access to data

trans-unit.source: Schema changes (DDL)
trans-unit.target: Schema changes (DDL)

trans-unit.source: Data changes (DML)
trans-unit.target: Data changes (DML)

trans-unit.source: Accounts, roles, and permissions (DCL)
trans-unit.target: Accounts, roles, and permissions (DCL)

trans-unit.source: Stored Procedure, Login and, Transaction Management.
trans-unit.target: Stored Procedure, Login and, Transaction Management.

trans-unit.source: For each Event Category, Auditing of Success and Failure operations are configured separately.
trans-unit.target: For each Event Category, Auditing of Success and Failure operations are configured separately.

trans-unit.source: For further details about the activities and events audited, see the Audit Log Format Reference (doc file download).
trans-unit.target: For further details about the activities and events audited, see the Audit Log Format Reference (doc file download).

trans-unit.source: Audit logs are stored in your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Audit logs are stored in your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can define an audit log retention period.
trans-unit.target: You can define an audit log retention period.

trans-unit.source: An auditing policy can be defined for a specific database or as a default server policy.
trans-unit.target: An auditing policy can be defined for a specific database or as a default server policy.

trans-unit.source: A default server auditing policy will apply to all databases on a server which do not have a specific overriding database auditing policy defined.
trans-unit.target: A default server auditing policy will apply to all databases on a server which do not have a specific overriding database auditing policy defined.

trans-unit.source: Before setting up audit auditing check if you are using a <linkText>"Downlevel Client"</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Before setting up audit auditing check if you are using a <linkText>"Downlevel Client"</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Launch the Azure Preview Portal at https://portal.azure.com.
trans-unit.target: Launch the Azure Preview Portal at https://portal.azure.com.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can also launch the Classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com/.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can also launch the Classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com/.

trans-unit.source: Refer to details below.
trans-unit.target: Refer to details below.

trans-unit.source: navigate to the configuration blade of the SQL Database / SQL Server you want to audit.
trans-unit.target: navigate to the configuration blade of the SQL Database / SQL Server you want to audit.

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings button on top and then, in the Setting blade, and select Auditing.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings button on top and then, in the Setting blade, and select Auditing.

trans-unit.source: In the auditing configuration blade, select STORAGE DETAILS to open the Audit Logs Storage Blade.
trans-unit.target: In the auditing configuration blade, select STORAGE DETAILS to open the Audit Logs Storage Blade.

trans-unit.source: Select the Azure storage account where logs will be saved and, the retention period.
trans-unit.target: Select the Azure storage account where logs will be saved and, the retention period.

trans-unit.source: Tip: Use the same storage account for all audited databases to get the most out of the preconfigured reports templates.
trans-unit.target: Tip: Use the same storage account for all audited databases to get the most out of the preconfigured reports templates.

trans-unit.source: Under LOGGING BY EVENT, click SUCCESS and FAILURE to log all events, or choose individual event categories.
trans-unit.target: Under LOGGING BY EVENT, click SUCCESS and FAILURE to log all events, or choose individual event categories.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Database, Click on To enforce auditing click here ... and on SECURITY ENABLED ACCESS select REQUIRED.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Database, Click on To enforce auditing click here ... and on SECURITY ENABLED ACCESS select REQUIRED.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Server you have two options: (a) after step #6, navigate for each SQL database on the server and apply this step, or (2) <linkText>Modify Server FDQN in the connection string</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Server you have two options: (a) after step #6, navigate for each SQL database on the server and apply this step, or (2) <linkText>Modify Server FDQN in the connection string</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Audit logs are aggregated in a collection of Store Tables with a SQLDBAuditLogs prefix in the Azure storage account you chose during setup.
trans-unit.target: Audit logs are aggregated in a collection of Store Tables with a SQLDBAuditLogs prefix in the Azure storage account you chose during setup.

trans-unit.source: You can view log files using a tool such as Azure Storage Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can view log files using a tool such as Azure Storage Explorer.

trans-unit.source: A preconfigured dashboard report template is available as a downloadable Excel spreadsheet to help you quickly analyze log data.
trans-unit.target: A preconfigured dashboard report template is available as a downloadable Excel spreadsheet to help you quickly analyze log data.

trans-unit.source: To use the template on your audit logs, you need Excel 2013 or later and Power Query, which you can download here.
trans-unit.target: To use the template on your audit logs, you need Excel 2013 or later and Power Query, which you can download here.

trans-unit.source: The template has fictional sample data in it, and you can set up Power Query to import your audit log directly from your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The template has fictional sample data in it, and you can set up Power Query to import your audit log directly from your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed instructions on working with the report template, read the How To (doc download).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed instructions on working with the report template, read the How To (doc download).

trans-unit.source: Launch the Classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com/.
trans-unit.target: Launch the Classic Azure Portal at https://manage.windowsazure.com/.

trans-unit.source: Click the SQL Database / SQL Server you want to audit, and then click the AUDITING & SECURITY tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the SQL Database / SQL Server you want to audit, and then click the AUDITING & SECURITY tab.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Database, On SECURITY ENABLED ACCESS select REQUIRED.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Database, On SECURITY ENABLED ACCESS select REQUIRED.

trans-unit.source: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Server you have two options: (a) after step #7, navigate for each SQL database on the server and apply this step, or (2) <linkText>Modify Server FDQN in the connection string</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you are configuring Auditing for a SQL Server you have two options: (a) after step #7, navigate for each SQL database on the server and apply this step, or (2) <linkText>Modify Server FDQN in the connection string</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: At the auditing section click ENABLED.
trans-unit.target: At the auditing section click ENABLED.

trans-unit.source: Edit the LOGGING BY EVENT as needed.
trans-unit.target: Edit the LOGGING BY EVENT as needed.

trans-unit.source: Select a STORAGE ACCOUNT and configure RETENTION.
trans-unit.target: Select a STORAGE ACCOUNT and configure RETENTION.

trans-unit.source: Click SAVE.
trans-unit.target: Click SAVE.

trans-unit.source: The description in this section refers to screen captures above.
trans-unit.target: The description in this section refers to screen captures above.

trans-unit.source: Either Azure Preview Portal or Classic Azure Portal may be used.
trans-unit.target: Either Azure Preview Portal or Classic Azure Portal may be used.

trans-unit.source: In production you are likely to refresh your storage keys periodically.
trans-unit.target: In production you are likely to refresh your storage keys periodically.

trans-unit.source: When refresh your keys you need to re-save the policy.
trans-unit.target: When refresh your keys you need to re-save the policy.

trans-unit.source: The process is as follows:.
trans-unit.target: The process is as follows:.

trans-unit.source: In the auditing configuration blade (described above in the set up auditing section) switch the Storage Access Key from Primary to Secondary and SAVE.
trans-unit.target: In the auditing configuration blade (described above in the set up auditing section) switch the Storage Access Key from Primary to Secondary and SAVE.

trans-unit.source: Go to the storage configuration blade and regenerate the Primary Access Key.
trans-unit.target: Go to the storage configuration blade and regenerate the Primary Access Key.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the auditing configuration blade, switch the Storage Access Key from Secondary to Primary and press SAVE.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the auditing configuration blade, switch the Storage Access Key from Secondary to Primary and press SAVE.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the storage UI and regenerate the Secondary Access Key (as preparation for the next keys refresh cycle.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the storage UI and regenerate the Secondary Access Key (as preparation for the next keys refresh cycle.

trans-unit.source: There are several PowerShell cmdlets you can use to configure auditing in Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: There are several PowerShell cmdlets you can use to configure auditing in Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: To access the auditing cmdlets you must be running PowerShell in Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: To access the auditing cmdlets you must be running PowerShell in Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title> module is currently in preview.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title> module is currently in preview.

trans-unit.source: It might not provide the same management capabilities as the Azure module.
trans-unit.target: It might not provide the same management capabilities as the Azure module.

trans-unit.source: When you are in Azure Resource Manager mode, run Get-Command *AzureSql* to list the available cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: When you are in Azure Resource Manager mode, run Get-Command *AzureSql* to list the available cmdlets.
